HeroUI has 50 Components, 43 of them are unique â€“ for example pagination and button group are considered as same.
HeroUI has light and dark themes
Does not support more than 2 themes at the same time

HeroUI has 208 third-party dependencies. Using more third-party dependencies increases the risk of security vulnerabilities, compatibility problems, and long-term maintenance headaches from deprecated packages.
HeroUI CSS file is not available on CDN
HeroUI requires changing JavaScript props one by one at build time to do design token customization
HeroUI does not provide micro CSS files for each component
HeroUI does not use wide-gamut P3 colors by default
HeroUI customizations requires changing JavaScript props at build time
HeroUI doesn not use native CSS nesting

<svg viewBox="0 0 1024 1024" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><rect x="256" y="670.72" width="512" height="256" rx="128" fill="#1AD1A5"/><circle cx="512" cy="353.28" r="256" fill="white"/><circle cx="512" cy="353.28" r="261" stroke="black" stroke-opacity="0.2" stroke-width="10"/><circle cx="512" cy="353.28" r="114.688" fill="#FF9903"/></svg>
daisyUI is framework agnostic and works everywhere
daisyUI has 61 components, 57 of them are unique â€“ for example pagination and button group are considered as same.
daisyUI supports unlimited themes at the same time, allowing for dynamic theme switching.
daisyUI doesn't ship JavaScript to browsers
daisyUI has no dependencies. It's immune to 3rd party vulnerabilities, dependency version mismatch, and deprecation issues.
In GitHub's top 400 repositories of all time
daisyUI CSS file is available on CDN
daisyUI provides tokens, root-level CSS variables and component-level CSS variables that let you adjust colors, sizes, spacing, radius, and other styles to match your design.
daisyUI can be used as a standalone file, with Tailwind CSS standalone version. This is useful for projects without a Node.js environment.
daisyUI provides micro CSS files for each component
daisyUI uses CSS variables for design customization at runtime
daisyUI uses native CSS nesting, reducing the CSS file size
How is daisyUI different from HeroUI?

HeroUI is a popular project on GitHub. daisyUI currently has more GitHub stars, suggesting a high level of interest from the developer community. HeroUI provides a useful set of components. daisyUI offers a larger number of components overall. daisyUI is intentionally designed to have zero dependencies
HeroUI provides a useful set of components. daisyUI offers a larger number of components overall.
HeroUI often applies themes during the build process. With daisyUI, you can switch themes instantly in the browser using CSS variables, without rebuilding.

HeroUI is a popular project on GitHub. daisyUI currently has more GitHub stars, suggesting a high level of interest from the developer community. HeroUI is frequently downloaded from NPM. daisyUI currently has more weekly downloads, suggesting it's being added to more projects each week
HeroUI is a popular project on GitHub. daisyUI currently has more GitHub stars, suggesting a high level of interest from the developer community.
HeroUI is frequently downloaded from NPM. daisyUI currently has more weekly downloads, suggesting it's being added to more projects each week.
daisyUI is intentionally designed to have zero dependencies.

daisyUI adds component class names to Tailwind CSS, like `btn`, `card`, etc. HeroUI often provides components using JavaScript frameworks. daisyUI focuses on using utility classes directly for styling.
